section.title: Overview
section.para: The &abelNGO; core ontologies ontologies-kernel are defined of three primary domain ontologies, as well as a bibliographical ontology and a set of domain subset ontologies. These ontologies are defined as to provide a uniform reference framework for instance ontologies, as may be defined within the &abelNGO; web portal and within distinct ontologies published by &abelNGO;
This onologies model is thus defined in three primary layers. The first two layers, in this model, are defined of the &abelNGO; core ontologies.

formalpara.title: Instance Ontologies
formalpara.para:
Application of Domain Subset Ontologies
For the initial proof of concept, the instance ontologies shall be defined onto a time period extending at least from Ukraine's independence, up to present circumstances. The geographic context of those instance ontologies shall be defined as with regards to a geographical region including of:
Ukraine Self-declared republics establishing independence from institutions in Kiev Crimea, as around her democratic realignment with Russia

sidebar.title: Hazards: Explosive Remnants of War (ERW)
sidebar.para: If it may be appropriate to define an additional ontological reference structure for purpose of denoting hazards now existing in Ukraine, certainly the hazards of land mines and of unexploded munitions should be well marked, locally — for safety of all people in Ukraine — pending a humanitarian countermine activity by qualified engineers.

formalpara.title: Root Namespace
formalpara.para: &abelNGO; core ontologies shall be defined in an HTTP namespace within the namespace of the &abelNGO; web site as hosted at GitHub Pages: http://abel-ngo.github.io/km/rdf/

section.title: &abelNGO; Domain Ontologies

formalpara.title: Ontological Reference Domains
formalpara.para:
The effective set of the &abelNGO; domain ontologies — that denoting, the set of ontologies defined by &abelNGO; and those ontologies within the import closure of those ontologies defined by &abelNGO; — shall be comprised of ontologies within three primary reference domains:
Events Social Entities and Personas Locales and Local Features

formalpara.title: Domain Subset Ontologies
formalpara.para: Each of the primary domain ontologies in the &abelNGO; ontologies kernel is extended with one or more ontologies for contextual typing and categorization of known events, entities, and locales, within the respective reference domain. The domain subset ontologies shall be defined as to provide a uniform reference framework for extension within individual instance ontologies

section.para: Moreover, an ontology is defined within the ontologies kernel, for definition of structural bibliographical references. This ontology is defined as to be applied in development of later instance ontologies.

formalpara.title: Instance Ontologies
formalpara.para: Resources extending of the &abelNGO; core entity ontologies may define individual instance layers, as extending on the respective reference domain ontologies and extensional domain subset ontologies.

section.title: Ontology Publication Procedure
section.para: The &abelNGO; Core Ontologies ontologies-kernel shall be published as web content, under the site for the &abelNGO; project, abel-ngo.github.io. The following outline provides an overview of tasks, for publishing the ontologies as to be available as web content within the HTTP view of the site:

step.para: Using Git, ensure that the remote abel-ngo.github.io source repository (origin) is cloned to the local site-repository-dir
Copy the set of ontologies from ontologies-kernel into the filesystem directory: site-repository-dir/km/rdf/

Using Git, add the new and/or updated ontologies from ontologies-kernel into the local source repository at the pathname site-repository-dir and check in the addition as a change to the repository contents
Using Git, push the change in site-repository-dir to the remote origin

section.para: To an extent, that workflow may be automated in using Ant. However, the automation would be complicated of the necessity for providing a user authentication service — as typically, utilizing an SSH key and an SSH authentication agent — for authenticating the local user to the remote repository. The integration with Git via Ant would be furthermore complicated, then, as for providing integration with an SSH authentication agent, across multiple operating system platforms. Therefore, the tasks involving Git will be left for manual implementation by the developer.

simplesect.title: Versioning with Ontology IRI
simplesect.para: An ontology extending on OWL 2 may define an optional ontology version IRI, as augmentative of the primary ontology IRI. The ontology version IRI would be relevant as when an ontology would be published in multiple versions, simultaneously.

For an ontology A published in a versioned sequence of ontologies A1 through An — with each ontology being defined with a unique ontology version IRI, respectively M1 through Mn — it may be expected that an ontology An would be available at the version IRI Mn. Furthermore, it may be expected that one of A1 through An would be available at the primary ontology IRI, M. In a practical regards, the simultaneous availability of ontologies A1 through An might be notably relevant, when the contents of an ontology An may differ substantially from the contents of ontology An+1, such that the ontology An would not be forwards compatible with the ontology An+1.

Although it is expected that the &abelNGO; core ontologies may be published in multiple versions, however the &abelNGO; core ontologies will not, by default, be defined with ontology version IRI. If, at some future time, any of the &abelNGO; core ontologies would be defined in a version Mn+1, such that the ontology would not be backward compatible with the ontology Mn, then the ontology M may be defined as a new ontology N, forked from M. That would serve as to allow for the incompatible definition of the ontology N, without adversely affecting functionality of software systems extending on the ontology Mn

simplesect.title: Version Specification in Ontology Metadata
simplesect.para: An ontology may be defined in a manner such as that the ontology definition would, in itself, be annotated with a version specifier. In this manner, the &abelNGO; core ontologies shall elect to use the Dublin Core Term hasVersion, as defined via the annotation property edition of the Dublin Core Terms ontologies published by Simon Reinhardt
